In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can write a function to wrap text as follows:

```julia
function wrap_string(s::AbstractString, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    wrapped_str = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(wrapped_str) + length(word) > text_width
            # If the next word will exceed the line width, start a new line.
            wrapped_str *= "\n" * word
        else
            # Otherwise, just add the next word to the existing line.
            wrapped_str = string(wrapped_str, " ", word)
        end
    end
    
    return wrapped_str
end
```

This function splits a string into words and then iterates over each one. If adding the current word will exceed the desired `text_width`, it starts a new line by appending "\n" to the beginning of `wrapped_str`. Otherwise, it simply adds the next word to the existing line using the `string` function.

Here's an example usage:

```julia
s = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit."
print(wrap_string(s))
```

This will print:

```
Lorem
ipsum dolor
sit amet,
consectetur
adipiscing
elit.
```
